Award.AwardTitle: Representations of Reductive Groups and Étale Hessenberg Varieties
Award.AbstractNarration:
The Langlands program, a central theme in contemporary number theory, comprises several predictions that provide an approach to the analytic study of solution sets of Diophantine equations using techniques from linear algebra to exploit hidden symmetries in these solution sets. Geometric representation theory brings geometric tools to bear in studying problems in linear algebra. This project will apply methods from geometric representation theory to first reduce the computation of certain integrals that arise in the Langlands program to a discrete problem in combinatorial geometry, and then to study the solution of this latter problem. The results are expected to deepen and extend understanding in number theory and geometric representation theory, areas of mathematics with connections to many other subjects, including cyber security and physics.

In work already completed, the investigator has succeeded in reducing the computation of certain orbital integrals to the problem of counting rational points of étale Hessenberg varieties over finite fields. This project will extend and refine the earlier computation, as well as study étale Hessenberg varieties in their own right, specifically as strata in affine Springer fibers, and place them in a broader context of relative Springer theory.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project is about an investigation of a new connection between number theory (the study of numbers) and representation theory (the study of symmetries). 
In one main part of representation theory studied (representations of p-adic groups, to be precise) in the project, we are concerned with certain numerical invariants called characters. These characters are themselves too complicated and are often more accessible by comparing with another type of invariant, called orbital integrals.
Part of the outcome of this project is to develop an algorithm to compute certain particularly orbital integrals (that have for example connection to knot theory). The algorithm has been freely distributed among a circle of experts and will hopefully help more further study.
A very important tool for the qualitatively study of the characters is the so-called "endoscopy." This term burrowed from medicine has a related but rather distinct meaning; at the intersection of number theory and representation theory, endoscopy is a technique (at the same time a phenomenon) that describes how symmetries of certain larger objects in number theory can be observed by inspecting symmetries of certain smaller "inside" objects. Conjectures around this concept has motivated a large portion of works in number theory, including Ngo's 2010 fields medal work.
This project has helped formulated another brand new conjecture relating endoscopy and classical representation theory (of finite groups of Lie type). This conjecture should lead to deeper study of the subject.
